{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3211981,"name":"Ian McTavish","username":"Ian_McTavish","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/b5a626/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-06-02T11:52:20.424Z","cooked":"

I am researching tools for electrical schematic and PCB design for my courses next year. I wanted to use easyEDA but their privacy policies prevent me from using it on school computers. What software do people recommend? Autodesk Eagle, SolidWorks electrical, Altium? Something else?
I would prefer a web based solution as students will have Chromebooks but do have Windows computers as well.

My primary goal is to have students create a variety of schematic diagrams for breadboard circuits that they make. Ideally the grades 11/12 students would design a custom PCB that we would manufacture.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-06-02T11:52:20.424Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":79,"reads":296,"readers_count":295,"score":454.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":437781,"topic_slug":"electrical-schematic-and-pcb-design-tools","display_username":"Ian McTavish","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17356,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/electrical-schematic-and-pcb-design-tools/437781/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3211983,"name":"Jared","username":"Japple","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-06-02T12:02:31.134Z","cooked":"

Well, there‚Äôs KiCAD. Good FOSS for schematic and PCB design

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-06-02T12:02:31.134Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":290,"readers_count":289,"score":108.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":437781,"topic_slug":"electrical-schematic-and-pcb-design-tools","display_username":"Jared","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58651,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"859(0/2)A"},"post_url":"/t/electrical-schematic-and-pcb-design-tools/437781/2","custom_user_title":"859(0/2)A","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3211991,"name":"Andy A.","username":"Andy_A","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andy_a/{size}/112162_2.png","created_at":"2023-06-02T12:50:02.318Z","cooked":"

Eagle is now part of Fusion 360s subscription service. I‚Äôm not sure what pricing looks like for educational users these days, but the added CAD/CAM software might make it an easier sell to the school. F360 will cloud sync design files, which is especially handy for electrical CAD, but so far as I know there‚Äôs no way to run it on a chrome book.

KiCAD and Eagle are fairly similar in terms of built in features and usability. They‚Äôre what I learned on, anyway. With adequate lesson prep on your part you can avoid a lot of the common frustrations that come with all EDA (primarily, part library management). They‚Äôre both old programs with a lot of tutorials, books and free part libraries available.

Altium used to be synonymous with intimidatingly expensive, powerful professional design tools aimed at commercial users. They have a few ‚Äòlight weight‚Äô tools now that are low cost or free for educational use. I have no experience with those, but they‚Äôre worth trying out.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-06-02T12:50:02.318Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":266,"readers_count":265,"score":58.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":437781,"topic_slug":"electrical-schematic-and-pcb-design-tools","display_username":"Andy A.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":58651,"username":"Japple","name":"Jared","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/ed8c4c/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":139,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Am I jumping around all nimbly-bimbly from tree to tree?"},"post_url":"/t/electrical-schematic-and-pcb-design-tools/437781/3","custom_user_title":"Am I jumping around all nimbly-bimbly from tree to tree?","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3211993,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2023-06-02T12:53:41.807Z","cooked":"

Altium gives you a license in your teams Digital KOP I believe, Eagle comes free with educational fusion 360 if you have someone with an Educator account set up a ‚Äúclass‚Äù for your team. KiCad is free as others have said. All have steep learning curves but that‚Äôs okay!

Fritzing can do PCBs‚Ä¶ You shouldn‚Äôt however trust it to actually do a proper job on its own. I have had hand made components be missed when I send the files directly from their in software ‚ÄúOrder a PCB‚Äù button. In the beginning teaching it might be useful for the breadboarding portions but otherwise don‚Äôt get sucked in to the idea that it can do what you need for PCBs.

Personally KiCad or Altium seem the most reasonable as Eagle on its own after they would leave the educational world is $1,500 per year almost‚Ä¶ KiCad will always be free and altium is still cheaper by a vast margin.

Back when I was in college I used Fritzing quite a bit - ended up ordering quite a few PCBs from them at one of my internships as well.

fritzing.org

Welcome to Fritzing

Fritzing is an electronics design and prototyping platform for makers, hobbyists, and educators. Easily create and document your electronic projects.

https://upverter.com/ was a decent web solution when I used it in college 5 years ago. Might work for the chrome book users. PCB Students - PCB Projects - Advanced Circuits might be a good place to start to get them made if you don‚Äôt have a plan for that already as well.

I mean, I‚Äôve used it to make these boards which we‚Äôre actually considering making:

Andy_A:

KiCAD and Eagle are fairly similar in terms of built in features and usability.

While this was true ten years ago, KiCAD has definitely outstripped Eagle today (at least in my opinion, having learned on Eagle).

For school, I‚Äôd use KiCAD. It‚Äôs easy to get set up with and works really well for simple projects. If you want something you‚Äôre more likely to use in industry, Altium is great and has a lot of powerful features. Just make sure to use the voucher in the KOP.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2023-06-02T21:58:45.183Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":148,"readers_count":147,"score":59.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":437781,"topic_slug":"electrical-schematic-and-pcb-design-tools","display_username":"Anand Rajamani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/electrical-schematic-and-pcb-design-tools/437781/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3212088,"name":"Adam","username":"awulfing","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/awulfing/{size}/233988_2.png","created_at":"2023-06-02T22:19:03.279Z","cooked":"
kingc95:

Altium gives you a license in your teams Digital KOP I believe

How did I not know this‚Ä¶

I‚Äôve used Altium, Kicad and Xpedition professionally, Eagle in college and tinked with allegro too.
Of all these Altium is definitely my favorite but pricing is insane if you cant get a good education deal. Kicad I would say my second choice given its very powerful for being a completely free software. Updating to newer versions is a pain though as you have to do a complete reinstall as it has busted my library‚Äôs in the past.

In case it‚Äôs helpful, I want to share a PCB grants program that we just opened up to fund up to $100 in manufacturing costs for PCB boards designed by high schoolers.

The program is run by Hack Club, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit and FIRST Alliance Partner. Here is the flow:

  1. Get PCB design tutorials, resources, and online events to learn how to make boards at Hack Club ‚Äì OnBoard
  2. Submit your PCB design files to GitHub - hackclub/OnBoard: üí° Join 1,000 teenagers and their journey in making their first PCB
  3. Receive up to $100 to fund a production run with JLCPCB, PCBWay, or another supported provider. You can do multiple design iterations up to a total cost of $100.

Requirements: Must be a current high school student or high school aged. Designs must also be made open source.

Please see this flyer to share with teams.
